facts.text: This is Civil Appeal No. 6 of 1954.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 6 of 1954. Appeal from the judgment

facts.text: Appeal from the judgment and order dated 8th June 1951 of Calcutta High Court in Income-tax Reference No. 1 of 1951.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal from the judgment -and order dated the 8th day of June 1951 of Calcutta High Court in Income-tax Reference No. 1 of 1951.

facts.text: The appellant is a timber merchant.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant is a timber merchant. On 5th February 1930. he obtained a loan of Rs. 1 lakh from the Bank of India

facts.text: On 5th February 1930, the appellant obtained a loan of Rs. 1 lakh from the Bank of India on the joint security of himself and one Mamraj Rambhagat.

anchor.surface_text: On 5th February 1930. he obtained a loan of Rs. 1 lakh from the Bank of India on the joint security of himself and one Mamraj Rambhagat.

facts.text: On the same day, Mamraj Rambhagat obtained a loan of Rs. 1 lakh from the Imperial Bank of India, Bombay on the joint security of himself and the appellant.

anchor.surface_text: On the same day Mamrai Rambhagat obtained -a loan of Rs. 1 lakh from the Imperial Bank of India., Bombay on the joint security of himself and the appellant.

facts.text: The appellant paid off his loan of Rs. 1 lakh to the Bank of India.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant paid off his loan of Rs. I lakh to the Bank of India but Mamraj Rambhagat failed to make good the amount of his loan

facts.text: Mamraj Rambhagat failed to make good the amount of his loan to the Imperial Bank of India, Bombay.

anchor.surface_text: but Mamraj Rambhagat failed to make good the amount of his loan to the Imperial Bank of India, Bombay. This sum of Rs. 1 lakh was realised

facts.text: Rs. 1 lakh with interest of Rs. 626 was realised by the Imperial Bank of India from the appellant on 24th March 1930.

anchor.surface_text: This sum of Rs. 1 lakh was realised by the Imperial Bank of India from the appellant with interest thereon of Rs. 626 on 24th March 1930.

facts.text: Mamraj Rambhagat failed in his business and his estate went into the hands of the receivers on 25th April 1930.

anchor.surface_text: Mamraj Rambhagat failed in his business and his estate went into the hands of the receivers on 25th April 1930.

facts.text: The appellant opened a ledger account in the name of Mamraj Rambhagat and debited Rs. 1,00,626 to this account.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant opened a ledger account in the name of Mamraj Rambhagat and the total amount of Rs. 1,00,626, was debited to this account.

facts.text: The appellant received dividends from the receivers: Rs.31,446 on 30th October 1930, Rs. 9,434 on 25th April 1934, Rs. 4,716 on 17th May 1938, aggregating Rs. 45,596.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant received the dividends from the receivers Rs.31,446 on 30th October 1930, Rs. 9,434 on 25th April 1934 and Rs. 4,716 on 17th May 1938, aggregating to Rs. 45 596

facts.text: Balance of Rs. 55,030 unpaid, written off as bad debt in assessment year 1941-42 (account year 1997 Ramnavmi).

facts.text: Claimed as allowable deduction under section 10 of the Act.

anchor.surface_text: as an allowable deduction under section 10 of the Act. The Income-tax Officer disallowed the claim holding that the said loss was a capital loss,

facts.text: Income-tax Officer disallowed the claim holding it was a capital loss.

facts.text: Appellate Assistant Commissioner also disallowed the claim.

arguments.claim: The loss of Rs. 55,030 is allowable as a bad debt under section 10(2)(xi) because it arose from standing surety in the course of the appellant's timber business pursuant to Bombay custom of joint security borrowings.

anchor.surface_text: It was argued on behalf of the appellant before the Appellate Assistant Commissioner that it was the usual custom in Bombay to secure loans on joint security from Banks by persons carrying on business. It was stated that this manner of securing loans on joint security was preferred by the Banks and it was also in the interest of the traders as lower rate

court_response_anchor.surface_text: for its decision- Whether on the facts found the sum of Rs. 55,030 is allowable as a bad debt under the provisions of section 10 2  xi  of the Indian

arguments.court_reasoning: Custom not proved to include mutuality; no part of loan used in appellant's business; debt not trading debt of timber business.

arguments.claim: Even assuming custom of joint security, the loss is capital because it is loss of sum borrowed by another for his own use, capital in nature.

anchor.surface_text: The Appellate Assistant Commissioner, however, distinguished the case on facts and held that even though the appellant stood surety for Mamraj Rambhagat in course of securing finance for his business of timber, it was the loss of a sum borrowed by another, the sum borrowed was capital in its nature and the loss suffered by the appellant

arguments.court_reasoning: Agreed loss capital, but further analyzed custom insufficiency.

arguments.claim: AAC did not opine on or require proof of custom, so custom accepted by Department; no distinction between money-lending and timber business financing; loss allowable following Ramaswamy Chettiar.

anchor.surface_text: On appeal taken by the appellant before the Income Tax Appellate Tribunal, the Tribunal was of the opinion that the Appellate Assistant Commissioner had not expressed any opinion in his order as to whether there was such custom or not nor had he asked the appellant to establish the custom. The Tribunal in these circumstances held that the custom

arguments.court_reasoning: Tribunal erred on facts (no part loan to appellant's business) and law (only trading debt deductible).

arguments.claim: No part of loan applied to appellant's business; only trading/business debt of appellant's trade deductible u/s 10(2)(xi); appellant not in surety or money-lending business; Ramaswamy confined to its facts per Subramanya Pillai.

anchor.surface_text: The said reference was heard by the High Court and in its judgment the High Court held that the Tribunal had proceeded on an erroneous assumption as to the facts of the case and the application of the money. Since no part of the loan, which had been taken from the Imperial Bank of India by Mamraj Rambhagat on the joint security of himself

arguments.court_reasoning: Endorsed and elaborated: custom unproved, mutuality absent, proper test is trading debt.

arguments.claim: Loss allowable as trading loss/bad debt because Bombay custom requires mutual suretyship (A sureties B in exchange for B suretying A), making it essential incident of financing timber business.

anchor.surface_text: The sole question for our determination in this appeal is whether the loss of Rs. 55,030 suffered by the appellant in this transaction was a capital loss or was a trading loss or a bad debt incurred by the appellant in the course of carrying on his business of timber. It is clear that no part of the monies borrowed on the joint security

arguments.court_reasoning: Custom not established to that mutuality extent; pronotes insufficient; AAC finding merely records statement.

arguments.claim: AAC finding that appellant stood surety in course of securing finance for timber business establishes the connection to business.

anchor.surface_text: Learned counsel for the appellant laid particular emphasis on the finding by the Appellate Assistant Commissioner that it was in the course of securing finance for the business of timber that he stood surety with Mamraj Rambhagat. This finding merely records the statement of fact, but does not go so far as to establish the custom

arguments.court_reasoning: Finding merely records statement, does not establish custom.

arguments.claim: No part of borrowed monies financed appellant's timber business; debt not due to appellant's timber business; if borrowed for own business, would be capital loss.

anchor.surface_text: It is clear that no part of the monies borrowed on the joint security of the appellant and Mamraj Rambhagat from the Imperial Bank of India, Bombay went to finance the timber business of the appellant, but they were all utilised by Mamraj Rambhagat in his own business.

arguments.claim: Custom alleged (mutual suretyship) not proved; joint security for lower interest does not imply mutuality; pronotes do not prove full custom.

anchor.surface_text: The custom stated before the Appellate Assistant Commissioner was that persons carrying on business in Bombay used to borrow monies on joint security from the Banks in order to facilitate getting financial assistance from the Banks and that too at lower rates of interest... The old pronotes jointly executed by the appellant and others... did not carry the case

arguments.claim: Transaction not in course of timber business; procuring finance essential but this suretyship wholly for Mamraj's business.

anchor.surface_text: The transaction in question could not, therefore, be deemed to be one entered into by the appellant in the course of or in carrying on his timber business. Procuring finances for his timber business would no doubt be an essential operation in the course of his carrying on his business, but the same thing could not be predicated

arguments.claim: Ramaswamy Chettiar not applicable: lacked mutuality and essentiality for timber business, unlike Nattukottai Chettiars' money-lending where mutual suretyship essential.

anchor.surface_text: The custom among the Nattukottai Chettiars held proved in Commissioner of Income-tax, Madras v. S. A. S. Ramaswamy Chettiar supra was that they stood surety for one another... There were thus elements of mutuality and the essential ingredient in the carrying on of the money lending business, which were elements of the custom proved in that case, both of which are wanting

arguments.claim: Subramanya Pillai analogous: joint borrowing not for assessee's sole business, loss not deductible u/s 10(2)(xi) or (xv).
Debt must be trading debt of the assessee's trade (timber); appellant not surety business or money-lender; even habitual suretyship for others would be capital loss.
Initial disallowance by ITO: loss is capital loss, not deductible.

anchor.surface_text: The Income-tax Officer disallowed the claim holding that the said loss was a capital loss, and so did the Appellate Assistant Commissioner.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: ficant to numbere that this case was distinguished by the learned Judges of the Madras High Court in Commissioner of Income-tax, Madras V. S. B. Subra

holdings.text: No part of the monies borrowed on the joint security of the appellant and Mamraj Rambhagat from the Imperial Bank of India, Bombay went to finance the timber business of the appellant, but they were all utilised by Mamraj Rambhagat in his own business.

anchor.surface_text: It is clear that no part of the monies borrowed on the joint security of the appellant and Mamraj Rambhagat from the Imperial Bank of India, Bombay went to finance the timber business of the appellant, but they were all utilised by Mamraj Rambhagat in his own business.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Direct application of facts to determine no connection to appellant's business; funds used solely by Mamraj.

holdings.text: The custom of mutual suretyship alleged by the appellant has not been proved, as the old pronotes did not establish mutuality or full scope of custom.

anchor.surface_text: The custom stated before the Appellate Assistant Commissioner was that persons carrying on business in Bombay used to borrow monies on joint security from the Banks in order to facilitate getting financial assistance from the Banks and that too at lower rates of interest... The old pronotes jointly executed by the appellant and others... did not carry the case

holdings.reasoning_summary: Evidence (pronotes) insufficient to prove mutuality required for custom to integrate suretyship into timber business.

holdings.text: The transaction in question could not be deemed to be one entered into by the appellant in the course of or in carrying on his timber business.

anchor.surface_text: The transaction in question could not, therefore, be deemed to be one entered into by the appellant in the course of or in carrying on his timber business. Procuring finances for his timber business would no doubt be an essential operation in the course of his carrying on his business, but the same thing could not be predicated

holdings.reasoning_summary: Suretyship was wholly for Mamraj's business financing, not appellant's, despite general need for finance.

holdings.text: The finding by the Appellate Assistant Commissioner that the appellant stood surety in the course of securing finance for his timber business merely records a statement of fact and does not establish the custom.

anchor.surface_text: Learned counsel for the appellant laid particular emphasis on the finding by the Appellate Assistant Commissioner that it was in the course of securing finance for the business of timber that he stood surety with Mamraj Rambhagat. This finding merely records the statement of fact, but does not go so far as to establish the custom

holdings.reasoning_summary: AAC finding is not evaluative of custom but mere recital; insufficient evidence beyond.

holdings.text: Elements of mutuality and essentiality present in Ramaswamy Chettiar (Nattukottai Chettiars' money-lending) are wanting here for timber business.

anchor.surface_text: The custom among the Nattukottai Chettiars held proved in Commissioner of Income-tax, Madras v. S. A. S. Ramaswamy Chettiar supra was that they stood surety for one another... There were thus elements of mutuality and the essential ingredient in the carrying on of the money lending business, which were elements of the custom proved in that case, both of which are wanting

holdings.reasoning_summary: Distinguishes precedent on facts: no mutuality or business necessity proven for appellant's trade.

holdings.text: Subramanya Pillai case furnishes the proper analogy and points to the right conclusion that the loss is not deductible under section 10(2)(xi) or (xv).
holdings.reasoning_summary: Analogous facts of joint borrowing not solely for assessee's business lead to non-deductibility.

holdings.text: The debt must be one which can properly be called a trading debt and a debt of the trade whose profits are being computed; here it is not, even if habitual suretyship occurred, it would be capital loss.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Applies statutory test under s.10(2)(xi): requires debt connected to assessee's specific trade (timber), not general suretyship; approves High Court test.

precedents.cited_holding: It is their custom to borrow from banks for the purpose of lending out the sums so obtained at higher rates of interest. The banks require such overdrafts to be guaranteed by other Chettiars. The Chettiars stand surety for one another in these borrowings.
